original: kena bhadanta bhagavan hetunā kena kāraṇena kīdṛśenottaptavīryeṇa kuśalamūlena yasya kṛtatvādupacitatvādevatāni jvalanāntaratejorājapramukhāni daśadevaputrasahasrāṇyetarhi trāyastriśaddevabhavanādāgatāni bhagavato'ntike dharmaśravaṇāyopasaṃkrāmanti /
analyzed: kena bhadanta bhagavan hetunā kena kāraṇena kīdṛśena uttapta vīryeṇa kuśala mūlena yasya kṛta tvāt upacita tvāt devatāni jvalana antara tejorāja pramukhāni daśa devaputra sahasrāṇi etarhi trāyastriśat deva bhavanāt āgatāni bhagavataḥ ntike dharma śravaṇāya upasaṃkrāmanti
translated: Blessed One, by what cause, by what reason, by what kind of ardent and wholesome root, by whose performance and accumulation, have the ten thousand deva sons headed by Jvalanāntara-tejas-rāja come now from the Trāyastriṃśa deva realm to approach the Blessed One to listen to the Dharma?

original: eteṣāṃ trayāṇāṃ satpuruṣāṇāṃ bodhisattvavyākaraṇaṃ śrutvā bodhau cittamutpādayanti /
analyzed: eteṣām trayāṇām sat puruṣāṇām bodhisattva vyākaraṇam śrutvā bodhau cittam utpādayanti
translated: Having heard the prophecy of enlightenment for these three good men, they generate the mind of enlightenment.

original: yathāyaṃ ruciraketuḥ satpuruṣo'nāgate'dhvani gaṇanāsamatikrānteṣvanekeṣvasaṃkhyeyakalpakoṭīniyutaśatasahasreṣvatikrānteṣu suvarṇaprabhāsitāyāṃ lokadhātāvanuttarāṃ samyakyaṃbodhimabhisaṃbhotsyate /
analyzed: yathā ayam ruciraketuḥ sat puruṣaḥ ūna āgata idhvani gaṇanā samatikrānteṣu anekeṣu asaṃkhyeya kalpa koṭī niyuta śata sahasreṣu atikrānteṣu suvarṇaprabhāsitāyām lokadhātau anuttarām samyakyaṃbodhim abhisaṃbhotsyate
translated: Just as this good man Ruciraketu will in the future, after countless, innumerable, many hundreds of thousands of niyutas of kotis of kalpas, in the world system called Suvarṇaprabhā, attain supreme perfect enlightenment,

original: suvarṇaratnākaracchatrakūṭo nāma tathāgato'rhansamyaksaṃbuddho loka utpatsyate vidyācaraṇasaṃpannaḥ sugato lokavidanuttaraḥ puruṣadamyasārathiḥ śāstā devānāṃ ca manuṣyāṇāṃ ca buddho bhagavan /
analyzed: suvarṇaratnākaracchatrakūṭaḥ nāma tathāgataḥ urhan samyaksaṃbuddhaḥ loke utpatsyate vidyā caraṇa saṃpannaḥ sugataḥ loka vid anuttaraḥ puruṣa damya sārathiḥ śāstā devānām ca manuṣyāṇām ca buddhaḥ bhagavan
translated: and will appear in the world as the Tathāgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One, perfect in knowledge and conduct, the Sugata, the Knower of the world, the Leader of men to be tamed, the Teacher of gods and men, the Buddha, the Blessed One, named Suvarṇaratnākara-chatra-kūṭa.

original: yāvattasya bhagavataḥ suvarṇaratnākaracchatrakūṭasya tathāgatasyārhataḥ samyaksaṃbuddhasya parinirvṛtasya saddharmāntarhite sarveṇa sarve sarvathā sarvaṃ tasya śāsanasyāntarhitasyāyaṃ rūpyaketurnāma dārakaḥ /
analyzed: yāvat tasya bhagavataḥ suvarṇaratnākaracchatrakūṭasya tathāgatasya arhataḥ samyaksaṃbuddhasya parinirvṛtasya saddharma antarhite sarveṇa sarve sarvathā sarvam tasya śāsanasya antarhitasya ayam rūpyaketuḥ nāma dārakaḥ
translated: And when that Blessed One Suvarṇaratnākara-chatra-kūṭa Tathāgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened One has attained final nirvāṇa, and the True Dharma has disappeared, then all of this teaching of his, completely and in every way, will disappear. And at that time, this boy named Rūpyaketu,

original: tasya tathāgatasyānusaṃghau tatra caiva virajadhvajalokadhātau suvarṇajambudhvajakāñcanābho nāma tathāgato'rhansamyaksaṃbuddho loka utpatsyate
analyzed: tasya tathāgatasya anusaṃghau tatra ca eva virajadhvaja lokadhātau suvarṇajambudhvajakāñcanābhaḥ nāma tathāgataḥ urhan samyaksaṃbuddhaḥ loke utpatsyate
translated: In the retinue of that Tathāgata, and in that very Virājadhvaja world system, a Tathāgata named Suvarṇa-jaṃbu-dhvaja-kāñcana-prabhāsa will appear in the world, a Worthy One, a Perfectly Enlightened One.

original: yāvattasya suvarṇadhvajakāñcanāvabhāsasya tathāgatasyārhataḥ samyaksaṃbuddhasya parinirvṛtasya sarveṇa sarve sarvathā sarvaṃ tasya śāsanasyāntarhitasyāyaṃ rūpyaprabho dārakaḥ /
analyzed: yāvat tasya suvarṇadhvajakāñcanāvabhāsasya tathāgatasya arhataḥ samyaksaṃbuddhasya parinirvṛtasya sarveṇa sarve sarvathā sarvam tasya śāsanasya antarhitasya ayam rūpyaprabhaḥ dārakaḥ
translated: And when the teaching of that Tathāgata Suvarṇa-dhvaja-kāñcana-prabhāsa, the Worthy One, the Perfectly Enlightened One, has completely disappeared, this boy Rūpya-prabha,

original: tasya tathāgatasyonusaṃghau tatra caiva virajadhvajalokadhātāvanuttarāṃ samyaksaṃbodhimabhisaṃbhotsyate /
analyzed: tasya tathāgatasya ūnu saṃghau tatra ca eva virajadhvaja lokadhātau anuttarām samyaksaṃbodhim abhisaṃbhotsyate
translated: in the retinue of that Tathāgata, will attain supreme perfect enlightenment in that very Virājadhvaja world system.

original: suvarṇaśataraśmiprabhāsagarbho nāma tathāgato'rhanasamyaksaṃbuddho loka utpasyate vidyācaraṇasampannaḥ sugato lokavidanuttaraḥ puruṣadamyasārathiḥ śāstā devānāṃ ca manuṣyāṇāṃ ca buddho bhagavān //
analyzed: suvarṇaśataraśmiprabhāsagarbhaḥ nāma vidyā caraṇa sampannaḥ sugataḥ loka vid anuttaraḥ puruṣa damya sārathiḥ śāstā devānām ca manuṣyāṇām ca buddhaḥ bhagavān
translated: He will appear in the world as the Tathāgata, the Worthy One, the Perfectly Enlightened One, endowed with knowledge and conduct, the Sugata, the knower of the world, the unexcelled guide for those to be tamed, the teacher of gods and humans, the Buddha, the Blessed One, named Suvarṇa-śata-raśmi-prabhāsa-garbha.

original: te sarva etarhi bhagavatānuttarāyāṃ samyak saṃbodhau vyākṛtāḥ //
analyzed: te sarve etarhi bhagavatā anuttarāyām samyak saṃbodhau vyākṛtāḥ
translated: They have all now been prophesied by the Blessed One to supreme perfect enlightenment.

original: na caiteṣāṃ bhadanta bhagavajjvalanāntaratejorājapramukhānāṃ daśānāṃ devaputrasahasrāṇāṃ yāvadvistīrṇā bodhisatvacaryā abhūvan /
analyzed: na ca eteṣām bhadanta bhagavat jvalana antara tejorāja pramukhānām daśānām devaputra sahasrāṇām yāvat vistīrṇāḥ bodhisatva caryāḥ abhūvan
translated: And these ten thousand sons of gods, headed by Bhadanta Bhagavat Jvalanantaratejoraja, did not have such extensive bodhisattva practices,

original: na ṣaṭsu pāramitāsu pūrvaṃ caritavantaḥ śrutapūrvā abhūvan /
analyzed: na ṣaṭsu pāramitāsu pūrvam caritavantaḥ śruta pūrvāḥ abhūvan
translated: and they had not previously practiced the six perfections, nor had they heard of them before.

original: nayanacaraṇottamāṅgapriyaputrabhāryāduhitaraḥ parityaktapūrvā na śrūyante /🔽dhanadhānyahiraṇyasuvarṇamaṇimuktāvajravaiḍūryaśaṅkhaśilāpravāḍajātarūparajatamarakataratnāni parityaktapūrvāṇi na śrūyante /🔽nānānnapānavastrayānaśayanāsanabhavanavimānārāmapuṣkariṇītaḍāgāḥ parityaktapūrvā na śrūiyante /
analyzed: nayana caraṇa uttamāṅga priya putra bhāryā duhitaraḥ parityakta pūrvāḥ na śrūyante  dhana dhānya hiraṇya suvarṇa maṇi muktā vajra vaiḍūrya śaṅkha śilā pravāḍa jātarūpa rajata marakata ratnāni parityakta pūrvāṇi na śrūyante  nānā anna pāna vastra yāna śayana āsana bhavana vimāna ārāma puṣkariṇī taḍāgāḥ parityakta pūrvāḥ na śrūiyante
translated: They had not previously given up their eyes, feet, head, beloved sons, wives, and daughters, nor was it heard of.🔽They had not previously given up wealth, grain, gold, silver, jewels, pearls, diamonds, lapis lazuli, conch shells, crystals, corals, refined gold, silver, and emerald gems, nor was it heard of.🔽They had not previously given up various foods, drinks, clothes, vehicles, beds, seats, houses, palaces, gardens, ponds, and lakes, nor was it heard of.

analyzed: nānā hasti go śva vaḍavā dāsī dāsāḥ parityakta pūrvāḥ na śrūyante
translated: They had not previously given up various elephants, cows, horses, mares, female servants, male servants, and slaves, nor was it heard of.

original: yathā tānyanekāni bodhisattvakoṭīniyutaśatasahasrāṇi pūrveṣvasaṃkhyeyakalpakoṭīniyutaśatasahasreṣvanekānāmasaṃkhyeyatathāgatakoṭīniyutaśatasahasrāṇāmanekācintyaiḥ nānāvicitraiḥ pūjāśatasahasraiḥ sarvopakaraṇaiḥ pūjāṃ kariṣyanti /
analyzed: yathā tāni anekāni bodhisattva koṭī niyuta śata sahasrāṇi pūrveṣu asaṃkhyeya kalpa koṭī niyuta śata sahasreṣu anekānām asaṃkhyeya tathāgata koṭī niyuta śata sahasrāṇām aneka acintyaiḥ nānā vicitraiḥ pūjā śata sahasraiḥ sarva upakaraṇaiḥ pūjām kariṣyanti
translated: Just as those many quintillions of bodhisattvas in the past, for many quintillions of countless eons, made offerings to many countless quintillions of tathāgatas with many inconceivable hundreds of thousands of various kinds of offerings,

analyzed: sarva ratna parityāgāni parityajiṣyanti
translated: they will give up all their jewels.

analyzed: kara caraṇa nayana uttamāṅga priya putra bhāryā duhitā parityāgāni kariṣyanti
translated: They will give up their hands, feet, eyes, heads, beloved sons, wives, and daughters.

analyzed: dhana dhānya hiraṇya suvarṇa maṇi muktā vaiḍūrya śaṅkha śilā pravāḍa rajata jātarūpāṇi parityāgāni parityajanti
translated: They will give up all their wealth, grain, silver, gold, jewels, pearls, beryl, conch shells, quartz, coral, and red pearls.

analyzed: anna pāna vastra śayana āsana bhavana vimāna ārāma udyāna puṣkariṇī hasti gavāśca vaḍavā dāsī dāsa parityāgāni parityakṣyanti
translated: They will give up their food, drink, clothes, bedding, seats, houses, palaces, parks, gardens, ponds, elephants, cows, horses, mares, female servants, and male servants.

analyzed: anupūrveṇa ṣaṣ pāramitāḥ paripūrayiṣyanti
translated: In due course they will perfect the six perfections.

analyzed: anupūrveṇa ṣaḍ pāramitāḥ paripūrayitvā anekāni sukha śata sahasrāṇi anubhaviṣyanti
translated: In due course, having perfected the six perfections, they will experience many hundreds of thousands of joys.

analyzed: yāvat buddhebhyaḥ bhagavat bhayaḥ tathāgata nāmadheye vyākaraṇam pratilapsyante
translated: until they receive a prophecy from the Buddhas, the Blessed Ones, of the name of the Tathāgata they will have in the future.”

original: tatkena bhadanta bhagavan hetunā kena kāraṇena kīdṛśenoptakuśalamūlena ca tāni jvalanāntarate jorājapramukhāni daśadevaputrasahasrāṇīha bhagavato'ntikaṃ dharmaśravaṇāyopasaṃkrāmanti /
analyzed: tat kena bhadanta bhagavan hetunā kena kāraṇena kīdṛśena upta kuśala mūlena ca tāni jvalana antarate jorāja pramukhāni daśa devaputra sahasrāṇi iha bhagavataḥ ntikam dharma śravaṇāya upasaṃkrāmanti
translated: “Bhagavān, what is the cause, what is the reason, what is the kind of root of merit that those ten thousand Mahābrahmās, with Puṇyaraśmi at their head, have planted, that they have come into the presence of the Bhagavān in order to hear the Dharma?

analyzed: tāni etarhi bhagavatā anuttarāyām samyaksaṃbodhau vyākṛtāni
translated: And now they have been prophesied by the Bhagavān to attain the highest, complete enlightenment.

analyzed: yat uta anāgata idhvani anekeṣu asaṃkhyeya kalpa koṭī niyuta śata sahasreṣu atikrānteṣu tatra iva śālendradhvajāgravatyām lokadhātau eka kula gotra eka nāmadheyena anupūrveṇa anuttarām samyaksaṃbodhim abhisaṃbhotsyante
translated: In the future, after many quintillions of eons have passed, in the world realm named Śāleṃdradhvajāgravatī, they will attain the highest, complete enlightenment of perfect buddhahood, all in the same family, in the same clan, and with the same name, Puṇyaraśmi.”

original: prasannavadanotpalagandhakūṭānāmnā daśasu dikṣu daśabuddhasahasrāṇi loka utpatsyante vidyācaraṇasaṃpannāḥ sugatā lokavido'nuttarāḥ puruṣadamyasārathayaḥ śāstāro devānāṃ ca manuṣyāṇāṃ ca buddhā bhagavantaḥ //
analyzed: prasannavadana utpala gandhakūṭa anāmnā daśasu dikṣu daśa buddha sahasrāṇi loke utpatsyante vidyā caraṇa saṃpannāḥ sugatāḥ loka vidaḥ unuttarāḥ puruṣa damya sārathayaḥ śāstāraḥ devānām ca manuṣyāṇām ca buddhāḥ bhagavantaḥ
translated: In the ten directions, ten thousand Buddhas will appear in the world, endowed with knowledge and conduct, Well-Gone, understanders of the world, supreme charioteers to be tamed, teachers of gods and humans, Buddhas, Blessed Ones, with names like Prasannavadanotpalagandhakuta.

analyzed: evam ukte bhagavān tām bodhisattvasamuccayām kuladevatām etat avocat
translated: When this was said, the Blessed One said to that family deity who had assembled the bodhisattvas:

analyzed: asti kuladevate sa hetuḥ asti tat kāraṇam
translated: Family deity, there is a cause, there is a reason.

original: asti taduptaṃ kuśalamūlaṃ yasya kṛtatvādupacitatvādetāni jvalanāntaratejorājapramukhāni daśadevaputrasahasrāṇyetarhi trāyastriṃśadbhavanādiha dharmaśravaṇāyopasaṃkrāmanti /
analyzed: asti tat uptam kuśala mūlam yasya kṛta tvāt upacita tvāt etāni jvalana antara tejorāja pramukhāni daśa devaputra sahasrāṇi etarhi trāyastriṃśat bhavanāt iha dharma śravaṇāya upasaṃkrāmanti
translated: There is that planted root of virtue, by which these ten thousand sons of gods headed by Jvalana-antara-tejo-raja have now come from the abode of the Thirty-Three to listen to the Dharma here, having planted it, having accumulated it.

original: eteṣāṃ trayāṇāṃ satpuruṣāṇāmidaṃ bodhivyākaraṇaṃ śrutvā sahaśravaṇena kuladevate'sya suvarṇaprabhāsottamasya sūtrendrarājasyāntike citrīkāraprītiprasādapratilabdhā bhavanti /
analyzed: eteṣām trayāṇām sat puruṣāṇām idam bodhi vyākaraṇam śrutvā saha śravaṇena kula devatā isya suvarṇaprabhāsa uttamasya sūtra indra rājasya antike citrīkāra prīti prasāda pratilabdhāḥ bhavanti
translated: Family deity, having heard this prophecy of enlightenment of these three good men, they attain joy, delight, and serene confidence in the presence of this excellent sutra king Suvarnaprabhasa, having heard it together.

analyzed: tāvat vimala vaiḍurya sadṛśena pariśuddha cittena samanvāgatāḥ bhavanti
translated: They become endowed with a mind that is as pure as a spotless beryl.

analyzed: vimala vipula vistīrṇa gagaṇa kalpa sadṛśena gambhīreṇa citta prasādena samanvāgatāḥ bhavanti
translated: They become endowed with a profound and clear mind that is as vast and extensive as the sky.

original: aparimitaṃ ca puṇyaskandhaṃ parigṛhītavanto bhavanti tāvaccaityadaivate jvalanāntaratejorājapramukhāni daśadevaputrasahasrāṇi sahaśravaṇenāsya sūtrendrarājasyāntike citrīkāraprasādapratilabdhā bhavanti /
analyzed: aparimitam ca puṇya skandham parigṛhītavantaḥ bhavanti tāvat caitya daivate jvalana antara tejorāja pramukhāni daśa devaputra sahasrāṇi saha śravaṇena asya sūtrendra rājasya antike citrīkāra prasāda pratilabdhāḥ bhavanti
translated: They have accumulated an immeasurable heap of merit. To that extent, the ten thousand devaputras headed by Jvalanantaratejoraja, the caityadevatas, upon hearing this king of sutras, attain faith and delight.

original: tāvadvimalavaiḍūryasadṛśena pariśuddhena cittena samanvāgatā bhavanti yāvadyākaraṇabhūmimanuprāptāḥ /
analyzed: tāvat vimala vaiḍūrya sadṛśena pariśuddhena cittena samanvāgatāḥ bhavanti yāvat yākaraṇa bhūmim anuprāptāḥ
translated: They become endowed with a mind that is as pure as a spotless beryl, to the extent that they attain the stage of prediction.

original: anena kuladevate dharmaśravaṇakuśalamūlapracayenāpi pūrvapraṇidhānavaśenaitāni jvalanāntaratejorājapramukhāni daśadevaputrasahasrāṇyetarhyanuttarāyāṃ samyaksaṃbodhau vyākṛtāni /
analyzed: anena kula devate dharma śravaṇa kuśala mūla pracayena api pūrva praṇidhāna vaśena etāni jvalana antara tejorāja pramukhāni daśa devaputra sahasrāṇi etarhi anuttarāyām samyaksaṃbodhau vyākṛtāni
translated: By this accumulation of roots of merit from listening to the Dharma, and by the power of their previous aspirations, these ten thousand devaputras headed by Jvalanantaratejoraja have now been predicted to unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.

analyzed: katamāni ca kula devate pūrva praṇidhānāni iti
translated: What were their previous aspirations, O Goddess?

analyzed: iti śrī suvarṇaprabhāsottama sūtra indrarāje daśadevaputrasahasravyākaraṇa parivartaḥ ṣoḍaśaḥ
translated: Thus concludes the chapter on the predictions to the ten thousand gods, the sixteenth in the glorious Suvarṇa-prabhāsa-uttama-sūtra-indrarāja.

original: vyādhipraśamanaparivartaḥ //🔽bhūtapūrvaṃ kuladevate'tīte'dhvanyasaṃkhyeyatarairvipulairacintyairaprameyairyadāsīttena kālena tena samayena ratnaśikhī nāma tathāgato'rhansamyaksaṃbuddho loka utpanno vidyācaraṇasaṃpannaḥ sugato lokavidanuttaraḥ puruṣadamyasārathiḥ śāstā devānāṃ ca manuṣyāṇāṃ ca buddho bhagavān /
analyzed: bhūta pūrvam kula devatā itīta idhvanya saṃkhyeyataraiḥ vipulaiḥ acintyaiḥ aprameyaiḥ yadā āsīt tena kālena tena samayena ratnaśikhī nāma tathāgataḥ urhan samyaksaṃbuddhaḥ loke utpannaḥ vidyā caraṇa saṃpannaḥ sugataḥ loka vid anuttaraḥ puruṣa damya sārathiḥ śāstā devānām ca manuṣyāṇām ca buddhaḥ bhagavān
translated: The Chapter on Curing Illness🔽In the past, O Goddess of the Family, in a time gone by, incalculable, vast, inconceivable, immeasurable, at that time, at that occasion, there appeared in the world a Tathāgata, an Arhat, a Perfectly Enlightened One named Ratnasaṃbhava, perfected in knowledge and conduct, a Sugata, a knower of the world, an unsurpassed trainer of those who can be trained, a teacher of gods and humans, a Buddha, a Blessed One.

original: tena khalu punaḥ kuladevate kālena tena samayena tasya bhagavato ratnaśikhinastathāgatasyārhataḥ samyaksaṃbuddhasya parinirvṛtasya saddharmasyāntarhitasya saddharmapratirūpake parivartamāne sureśvaraprabho nāma rājā babhūva /
analyzed: tena khalu punar kuladevate kālena tena samayena tasya bhagavataḥ ratnaśikhinaḥ tathāgatasya arhataḥ samyaksaṃbuddhasya parinirvṛtasya saddharmasya antarhitasya saddharma pratirūpake parivartamāne sureśvaraprabhaḥ nāma rājā babhūva
translated: At that time, O Goddess of the Family, at that occasion, after the Blessed One Ratnasaṃbhava, the Tathāgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One had passed into parinirvāṇa, and the True Dharma had disappeared, when the semblance of the True Dharma was in decline, there was a king named Sureśvara-prabha.

original: dhārmiko dharmarājo dharmeṇa rājyaṃ pālayamāno nādharmeṇa mātāpitṛkalpaḥ sarvaviṣayavāsināṃ sattvānām //
analyzed: dhārmikaḥ dharma rājaḥ dharmeṇa rājyam pālayamānaḥ na adharmeṇa mātā pitṛ kalpaḥ sarva viṣaya vāsinām sattvānām
translated: The righteous Dharma King, who ruled his kingdom righteously, not unrighteously, was like a mother and father to all the beings living in his realm.

original: tena khalu punaḥ kuladevate kālena tena samayena tasya rājñaḥ sureśvaraprabhasya viṣaye jaṭiṃdharo nāma śreṣṭhī babhūva //
analyzed: tena khalu punar kuladevate kālena tena samayena tasya rājñaḥ sureśvaraprabhasya viṣaye jaṭiṃdharaḥ nāma śreṣṭhī babhūva
translated: At that time, at that moment, in the realm of King Sureśvara-prabha, there was a guild master named Jaṭiṃdhara.

analyzed: vaidyaḥ cikitsakaḥ parama dhātu kuśa loṣṭa aṅgena āyurvaidya śāsreṇa samanvāgataḥ babhūva
translated: He was a physician, a healer, supremely skilled in the science of medicine, and possessed the eight branches of the medical teachings.

original: tena khalu kuladevate kālena tena samayena tasya jaṭiṃdharasya śreṣṭhino jalavāhano nāmnā śreṣṭhiputra utpanno babhūva /
analyzed: tena khalu kuladevate kālena tena samayena tasya jaṭiṃdharasya śreṣṭhinaḥ jalavāhanaḥ nāmnā śreṣṭhi putraḥ utpannaḥ babhūva
translated: At that time, at that moment, the guild master Jaṭiṃdhara had a son, a guild master's son named Jala-vahana.

original: abhirūpaḥ prāsādiko darśanīyaḥ paramayā śubhavarṇapuṣkaratayā samanvāgato nānāśāstrakuśalaḥ sarvaśāstragatiṃgato lipisaṃkhyāgaṇanākuśalaḥ sarvaśilpī babhūva /
analyzed: abhirūpaḥ prāsādikaḥ darśanīyaḥ paramayā śubha varṇa puṣkara tayā samanvāgataḥ nānā śāstra kuśalaḥ sarva śāstra gatiṃgataḥ lipi saṃkhyā gaṇanā kuśalaḥ sarva śilpī babhūva
translated: He was handsome, pleasing to the eye, supremely endowed with good fortune and beauty, skilled in various scriptures, had mastered all the scriptures, was skilled in writing, counting, and calculation, and was a master of all crafts.

original: tena khalu punaḥ kuladevate kālena tena samayena tasya rājñaḥ sureśvaraprabhasya viṣaye'nekāni sattvaśatasahasrāṇi nānārogaspṛṣṭānyabhūvan /
analyzed: tena khalu punar kuladevate kālena tena samayena tasya rājñaḥ sureśvaraprabhasya viṣayena ekāni sattva śata sahasrāṇi nānā roga spṛṣṭāni abhūvan
translated: At that time, O Kuladevi, in the realm of King Sureśvara-prabha, there were many hundreds of thousands of beings afflicted with various diseases.

original: nānāvyādhiparipīḍitāni duḥkhāṃ tīvrāṃ kharāṃ kaṭukāmamanāpāṃ vedanāṃ vedayanti //
analyzed: nānā vyādhi paripīḍitāni duḥkhām tīvrām kharām kaṭukām amanāpām vedanām vedayanti
translated: They were tormented by various illnesses and experienced painful, intense, harsh, bitter, and unpleasant feelings.

original: tena khalu punaḥ kuladevate kālena tena samayena tasya jalavāhanasya śreṣṭhiputrasya teṣāmanekeṣāṃ sattvaśatasahasrāṇāṃ nānārogaspṛṣṭānāṃ nānāvyādhiparipiḍitānāmarthāya paramakāruṇyaṃ cittamutpanno babhūva /
analyzed: tena khalu punar kuladevate kālena tena samayena tasya jalavāhanasya śreṣṭhi putrasya teṣām anekeṣām sattva śata sahasrāṇām nānā roga spṛṣṭānām nānā vyādhi paripiḍitānām arthāya parama kāruṇyam cittam utpannaḥ babhūva
translated: At that time, O Kuladevi, for the sake of those many hundreds of thousands of beings afflicted with various diseases and tormented by various illnesses, Jālavāhana, the merchant's son, generated the mind of supreme compassion.

original: etānyanekāni sattvaśatasahasrāṇi nānārogaspṛṣṭāni nānāvyādhiparipīḍitānyetarhi duḥkhāṃ tīvrāṃ kharāṃ kaṭukāmamanāpāṃ vedanāṃ vedayanti /
analyzed: etāni anekāni sattva śata sahasrāṇi nānā roga spṛṣṭāni nānā vyādhi paripīḍitāni etarhi duḥkhām tīvrām kharām kaṭukām amanāpām vedanām vedayanti
translated: These many hundreds of thousands of beings, afflicted with various diseases and tormented by various illnesses, are now experiencing painful, intense, harsh, bitter, and unpleasant feelings.

original: ayaṃ ca mama pitā jaṭiṃdharaḥ śreṣṭhī vaidyavicikitsakaḥ paramadhātukuśalo'ṣṭāṅgāyurvaidyaśāstreṇa samanvāgato vṛddho jīrṇo mahallako'dhvagato vayo'nuprāpto jīrṇamavasthāpya pravepamāṇaḥ kāyo yaṣṭimālambya yatra yatra sarvatra grāmanagaranigamarāṣṭrarājadhānīṣūpasaṃkrāmati /
analyzed: ayam ca mama pitā jaṭiṃdharaḥ śreṣṭhī vaidya vicikitsakaḥ parama dhātu kuśa loṣṭa aṅga āyurvaidya śāstreṇa samanvāgataḥ vṛddhaḥ jīrṇaḥ mahallaka ūdhva gataḥ vayaḥ anuprāptaḥ jīrṇam avasthāpya pravepamāṇaḥ kāyaḥ yaṣṭim ālambya yatra yatra sarvatra grāma nagara nigama rāṣṭra rājadhānīṣu upasaṃkrāmati
translated: And this father of mine, the merchant Jatila, is a physician, skilled in the supreme science of medicine, possessing the knowledge of the eight branches of Ayurveda. He is old, aged, advanced in years, advanced in seniority, advanced in time, his body trembling, leaning on a staff wherever he goes, in all villages, towns, cities, countries, and capitals.

original: etānyanekāni sattvaśatasahasrāṇi nānārogaspṛṣṭāni nānāvyādhiparipīḍitāni nānāvyādhobhyaḥ parimocayituṃ yaṃ nūnamahamimameva pitaraṃ jaṭiṃdharamupasaṃkramitvādhikauśalyaṃ paripṛccheyam /
analyzed: etāni anekāni sattva śata sahasrāṇi nānā roga spṛṣṭāni nānā vyādhi paripīḍitāni nānā vyādhobhyaḥ parimocayitum yam nūnam aham imam eva pitaram jaṭiṃdharam upasaṃkramitvā adhi kauśalyam paripṛccheyam
translated: Having seen him, I thought, 'These many hundreds of thousands of beings, afflicted with various diseases, tormented by various illnesses, should be liberated from various diseases. Therefore, I should approach this very father of mine, Jatila, and ask him about the highest skill.

analyzed: yena dhātu kauśalyena paripṛṣṭena aham sarvatra grāma nagara nigama janapada rāṣṭra rājadhānīṣu upasaṃkramiṣyāmi
translated: By what skill in the elements, having been asked, I will go everywhere to villages, towns, cities, countries, kingdoms, and capitals.

original: upasaṃkramya tānyanekāni sattvaśatasahasrāṇi nānārogaspṛṣṭāni nānāvyādhiparipīḍitāni nānāvyādhibhyaḥ parimocayiṣyāmi /
analyzed: upasaṃkramya tāni anekāni sattva śata sahasrāṇi nānā roga spṛṣṭāni nānā vyādhi paripīḍitāni nānā vyādhibhyaḥ parimocayiṣyāmi
translated: Having gone there, I will liberate those many hundreds of thousands of beings, afflicted with various diseases, tormented by various illnesses, from various diseases.'🔽Having thought thus, I approached my father, the merchant Jatila, and asked him about the highest skill.

original: tena khalu punaḥ kuladevate kālena tena samayena jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhiputro yena svapitā jaṭiṃdharaḥ śreṣṭhī tenopajagāma /🔽upetya svapiturjaṭiṃdharasya pādau śirasā vanditvā kṛtāñjalipuṭo bhūtvaikānte'sthāt /
analyzed: tena khalu punar kuladevate kālena tena samayena jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhi putraḥ yena sva pitā jaṭiṃdharaḥ śreṣṭhī tena upajagāma  upetya sva pituḥ jaṭiṃdharasya pādau śirasā vanditvā kṛta añjali puṭaḥ bhūtvā ekānte sthāt
translated: At that time, O Kuladevi, the merchant's son Jalavahana went to his own father Jatin-dhara the merchant.🔽Having approached, he bowed his head at the feet of his father Jatin-dhara, and with palms joined in reverence, stood to one side.

original: ekānte sthito jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhiputraḥ svapitaraṃ jaṭiṃdharaṃ śreṣṭhinamimābhirgāthābhirdhātukauśalyaṃ pṛcchati sma //
analyzed: ekānte sthitaḥ jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhi putraḥ sva pitaram jaṭiṃdharam śreṣṭhinam imābhiḥ gāthābhiḥ dhātu kauśalyam pṛcchati sma
translated: Standing to one side, the merchant's son Jalavahana asked his father Jatin-dhara the merchant about the skill in the elements with these verses:

analyzed: tāni indriyāṇi lakṣante parivartanti dhātavaḥ
translated: Those sense faculties are observed, the elements change.

analyzed: kena kālena jāyante vyādhayaḥ ca śarīriṇām
translated: In what time do diseases arise for embodied beings?

original: bhojanaṃ ca kathaṃ bhuktvā kāle kāle sukhāvaham /
analyzed: bhojanam ca katham bhuktvā kāle kāle sukha āvaham
translated: And how, eating food at the proper time, is it beneficial?

analyzed: yena antara śarīrasya kāya agninā upahanyate  /
translated: By what is the inner body's fire impaired?

original: kathaṃ cikitsā kartavyā vāte pitte śleṣmike tathā /
analyzed: katham cikitsā kartavyā vāte pitte śleṣmike tathā
translated: And how should treatment be done for wind, bile, and phlegm,

analyzed: saṃnipāte samutpanne katham vyādhi śāntaye
translated: and when all three are present, how to pacify the disease?

original: kiṃ kāle kupyate vātaḥ pittaṃ kupyate kadā /
analyzed: kim kāle kupyate vātaḥ pittam kupyate kadā
translated: When does wind get angry, when does bile get angry?

original: kiṃ kāle kupyate śleṣmā yena pīḍyanti mānavāḥ // //
analyzed: kim kāle kupyate śleṣmā yena pīḍyanti mānavāḥ
translated: In which season does phlegm get aggravated, by which people are afflicted?

original: atha khalu jaṭiṃdharaḥ śreṣṭhī jalavāhanasya śreṣṭhiputrasyābhirgāthābhirdhātukauśalyaṃ viditvā deśayate sma //
analyzed: atha khalu jaṭiṃdharaḥ śreṣṭhī jalavāhanasya śreṣṭhi putrasya ābhiḥ gāthābhiḥ dhātu kauśalyam viditvā deśayate sma
translated: Then indeed, the merchant Jatin-dhara, having understood the skill in the elements through the verses of the merchant Jalavahana's son, taught:

original: varṣā cātra trayo māsāstrayaśca śāradaṃ smṛtam /
analyzed: varṣā ca atra trayaḥ māsāḥ trayaḥ ca śāradam smṛtam
translated: Here, three months are the rainy season, three are remembered as autumn,

analyzed: trayaḥ tathā eva hemāntaḥ trayaḥ ca grīṣmikaḥ tathā
translated: three are the winter season, and three are likewise the summer.

analyzed: iti eva māsa kramaḥ ṣaṣ ṛtūni
translated: Thus, the sequence of months is six seasons,

analyzed: saṃvatsara dvādaśa māsikam smṛtam
translated: the year is remembered as having twelve months.

original: annaṃ ca pānaṃ ca tathā ca jīryate
analyzed: annam ca pānam ca tathā ca jīryate
translated: Food and drink are digested accordingly,

analyzed: vaidyāḥ ca kauśalya smṛti pradarśitāḥ
translated: and the physicians are shown by skill and mindfulness.

analyzed: te ca api saṃvatsara parvam antare  parivartanti indriya dhātavaḥ api
translated: And they also change in the intervals of the year's seasons,🔽and the sense faculties and elements also change.

analyzed: parivartamānāni ca indriyāṇi
translated: And the sense faculties that are changing

analyzed: vicitra vyādhiḥ bhavate śarīriṇām
translated: cause various illnesses in embodied beings.

analyzed: tatra eva vaidyasya catuḥ
translated: There, the physician's four types

analyzed: tri māsa parva antare ṣaṣ ṛtūni
translated: in the intervals of the three-month seasons, the six seasons,

analyzed: ṣaṣ dhātu kauśalya prajānitavyam
translated: the skill in the six elements should be known,

analyzed: yathākramam bhojanam auṣadham ca
translated: the food and medicine in sequence.

analyzed: vāta adhikārāḥ prabhavanti varṣe
translated: The disorders of wind predominate in the rainy season,

analyzed: patti prakopaḥ śaradi prasanne
translated: Aggravation of the bodily humors in autumn, when the sun is clear,

analyzed: hemanta kāle saṃnipātam
translated: And in winter, when there is a combination of cold and wind,

analyzed: kapha adhikārāḥ ca bhavanti grīṣme
translated: And predominance of phlegm in summer,

original: snigdhoṣṇalavaṇāmlarasāśca varṣe🔽śaratsu snigdhaṃ madhuraṃ ca śītam /
analyzed: snigdha uṣṇa lavaṇa amla rasāḥ ca varṣe  śaratsu snigdham madhuram ca śītam
translated: Oily, hot, salty and sour tastes in the rainy season,🔽Oily, sweet and cold in autumn,🔽Sweet, sour and oily in winter,

analyzed: madhura amla snigdham ca hemanta kāle  rūkṣa uṣṇa kaṭukāni ca grīṣma kāle
translated: And dry, hot and pungent in summer,

analyzed: kapha adhikaḥ kupyati bhukta mātre  pitta adhikam kupyati jīryamāṇe
translated: One with excess phlegm gets angry immediately after eating,🔽One with excess bile gets angry when being digested,

analyzed: vāta adhikaḥ kupyati jīrṇa mātre
translated: And one with excess wind gets angry immediately after digestion.

analyzed: iti eva dhātu tritaya prakopaḥ
translated: Thus, the three humors get aggravated.

analyzed: saṃbṛhaṇam kurvatu nirātmakasya
translated: One should do nourishing therapy for one without self,

analyzed: virecanam pitta vivardhanam ca
translated: And purgation which increases pitta,

analyzed: triguṇa upapannam saṃnipāte
translated: In the case of a combination of the three humors,

analyzed: praśamam ca kuryāt kapha parvam antare
translated: And one should also bring about pacification in the midst of phlegm and joints.

original: vātādhikaṃ paittikasannipāte🔽kaphādhikaṃ parvasu jānitavyam /🔽yatkāla yaddhātu yadāśrayaṃ ca
analyzed: vāta adhikam paittika sannipāte  kapha adhikam parvasu jānitavyam  yad kāla yad dhātu yad āśrayam ca
translated: One with excess wind in a combination of pitta and kapha,🔽And one with excess phlegm in the joints should be known.

analyzed: tat anna pāna oṣadhi darśitavyam iti
translated: The food, drink and medicine should be shown according to the time, the humor and the basis.

original: atha khalu jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhiputrastenaivaṃrūpeṇa naimittikena dhātukauśalyena paripṛṣṭena sarvāṣṭāṅgāyurvaidyamadhigato'bhūt /
analyzed: atha khalu jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhi putraḥ tena evaṃrūpeṇa naimittikena dhātu kauśalyena paripṛṣṭena sarva aṣṭāṅga āyurvaidyam adhigataḥ bhūt
translated: Then, Blessed One, the merchant's son Jālin gave the king a detailed explanation of the eight branches of medical science, and the king became well.

original: tena khalu punaḥ kuladevate kālena tena samayena jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhiputro rājñaḥ sureśvaraprabhasya viṣaye sarvagrāmanagaranigamajanapadarāṣṭrarājadhānīṣūpasaṃkramitvā sarveṣāmanekeṣāṃ sattvaśatasahasrāṇāṃ nānārogaspṛṣṭānāṃ nānāvyādhiparipīḍitānāmevamāśvāsayāmāsa /
analyzed: tena khalu punar kuladevate kālena tena samayena jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhi putraḥ rājñaḥ sureśvaraprabhasya viṣaye sarva grāma nagara nigama janapada rāṣṭra rājadhānīṣu upasaṃkramitvā sarveṣām anekeṣām sattva śata sahasrāṇām nānā roga spṛṣṭānām nānā vyādhi paripīḍitānām evam āśvāsayāmāsa
translated: Then, Blessed One, the merchant's son Jālin went to the city of Vārāṇasī, and in the city of Vārāṇasī he proclaimed:

original: mā bhaiṣurvaidyo'smi vaidyo'smītyātmānaṃ pratijñātavānahaṃ yuṣmākaṃ nānāvyādhibhyaḥ parimocayiṣyāmi /
analyzed: mā bhaiṣuḥ vaidyaḥ asmi vaidyaḥ asmi iti ātmānam pratijñātavān aham yuṣmākam nānā vyādhibhyaḥ parimocayiṣyāmi
translated: I am a doctor, I am a doctor! I will cure all of you who are sick and suffering from various diseases!

original: sahaśravaṇena kuladevate tasya jalavāhanasya śreṣṭhiputrasyedamevaṃrūpaṃ vacanaṃ vyāharamāṇasya sarvāṇi tānyanekāni sattvakoṭīniyutaśatasahasrāṇi mahāpraharṣajātāni babhūvuḥ /
analyzed: saha śravaṇena kula devate tasya jalavāhanasya śreṣṭhi putrasya idam evaṃrūpam vacanam vyāharamāṇasya sarvāṇi tāni anekāni sattva koṭī niyuta śata sahasrāṇi mahā praharṣa jātāni babhūvuḥ
translated: Blessed One, as soon as the people heard the words of the merchant's son Jālin, they were filled with great joy.

analyzed: āśvāsa prāptāni acintya prīti saumanasyena samanvāgatāni babhūvuḥ
translated: They were filled with inconceivable joy and happiness.

original: tāni tena kālena tena samayena tayā praharṣayānekāni sattvakoṭīniyutaśatasahasrāṇi nānārogaspṛṣṭāni nānāvyādhiparipīḍitāni nānārogebhyaḥ parimocayitānyarogāṇi ca babhūvurvigatavyādhīni ca /
analyzed: tāni tena kālena tena samayena tayā praharṣayā anekāni sattva koṭī niyuta śata sahasrāṇi nānā roga spṛṣṭāni nānā vyādhi paripīḍitāni nānā rogebhyaḥ parimocayitāni arogāṇi ca babhūvuḥ vigata vyādhīni ca
translated: At that time, at that moment, through that delight, many hundreds of thousands of millions of billions of beings who were afflicted by various diseases and tormented by various illnesses were freed from their various illnesses and became free from disease and free from illness.

original: yathā paurāṇena sthāmabalavīryeṇa samanvāgatāni babhūvuḥ /🔽tena khalu punaḥ kuladevate kālena tena samayena teṣāmanekeṣāṃ ca sattvakoṭīniyutaśatasahasrāṇāṃ nānārogaspṛṣṭānāṃ nānāvyādhiparipīḍitānāṃ ye kecidgāḍhatareṇa spṛṣṭā ca babhūvuḥ /
analyzed: yathā paurāṇena sthāma bala vīryeṇa samanvāgatāni babhūvuḥ  tena khalu punar kuladevate kālena tena samayena teṣām anekeṣām ca sattva koṭī niyuta śata sahasrāṇām nānā roga spṛṣṭānām nānā vyādhi paripīḍitānām ye kecid gāḍhatareṇa spṛṣṭā ca babhūvuḥ
translated: They became endowed with the strength, power, and energy they had before.🔽At that time, at that moment, among those many hundreds of thousands of millions of billions of beings who were afflicted by various diseases and tormented by various illnesses, there were some who were afflicted by very severe [diseases].

original: te sarve yena jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhiputrastenopasaṃkrānta upasaṃkramyaiva ye ca kiṃcitteṣāṃ sattvakoṭīniyutaśatasahasrāṇāṃ nānārogaspṛṣṭānāṃ nānāvyādhiparipīḍitānāmauṣadhividhānānyabhinirdiśanti sma /
analyzed: te sarve yena jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhi putraḥ tena upasaṃkrāntaḥ upasaṃkramya eva ye ca kiṃcid teṣām sattva koṭī niyuta śata sahasrāṇām nānā roga spṛṣṭānām nānā vyādhi paripīḍitānām auṣadhi vidhānāni abhinirdiśanti sma
translated: They all went to the merchant's son Jalavahana. Having approached, they pointed out various medicinal preparations for those many hundreds of thousands of millions of billions of beings who were afflicted by various diseases and tormented by various illnesses.

original: tattāsu rājadhānīṣu sarvāṇi tānyanekāni sattvakoṭīniyutaśatasahasrāṇi nānārogaspṛṣṭāni nānāvyādhiparipīḍitāni jalavāhanena śreṣṭhiputreṇa nānāvyādhibhyaḥ parimocitāni babhūvuriti //🔽iti śrīsuvarṇaprabhāsottamasūtrendrarāje vyādhipraśamana
analyzed: tat tāsu rājadhānīṣu sarvāṇi tāni anekāni sattva koṭī niyuta śata sahasrāṇi nānā roga spṛṣṭāni nānā vyādhi paripīḍitāni jalavāhanena śreṣṭhi putreṇa nānā vyādhibhyaḥ parimocitāni babhūvuḥ iti  iti
translated: Thus, in those royal capitals, all those many hundreds of thousands of millions of billions of beings afflicted with various diseases and tormented by various illnesses were freed from various diseases by Jālavāhana, the merchant's son.

analyzed: parivartaḥ nāma saptadaśaḥ
translated: Thus in the excellent sūtra king Suvarṇa-prabhāsa, the chapter on the pacification of diseases is the seventeenth.

analyzed: jala vāhanasya matsya vaineya parivartaḥ
translated: The chapter on Jālavāhana's guiding of fish.

original: punaraparaṃ kuladevate rājñaḥ sureśvaraprabhasya viṣaye jalavāhanena śreṣṭhidārakeṇa sarvasattvā ārogāḥ kṛtā alpā bādhā yathāpūrveṇotsāhabalakāyena saṃvṛtāḥ sarva utsāhasukhena ramanti sma /
analyzed: punar aparam kuladevate rājñaḥ sureśvaraprabhasya viṣaye jalavāhanena śreṣṭhi dārakeṇa sarva sattvāḥ ārogāḥ kṛtāḥ alpā bādhā yathāpūrveṇa utsāha balakāyena saṃvṛtāḥ sarve utsāha sukhena ramanti sma
translated: Moreover, Kuladevatā, in the realm of King Sureśvara-prabha, all beings were made well by the merchant's son Jālavāhana, with little affliction, as before, endowed with the strength of enthusiasm, all delighted with the happiness of enthusiasm,

analyzed: krīḍanti sma  paricārayanti sma
translated: they played,🔽they served,

analyzed: dānāni ca dadanti sma
translated: they gave gifts,

analyzed: puṇyāni ca kurvanti sma
translated: and they made merit.

original: jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhidārako mahāvaidyadānānāṃ ca sukhānāṃ vyādhivicikitsako niyatapratyakṣeṇa bodhisattvena bhavitavyam /
analyzed: jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhi dārakaḥ mahā vaidya dānānām ca sukhānām vyādhi vicikitsakaḥ niyata pratyakṣeṇa bodhisattvena bhavitavyam
translated: The merchant's son Jālavāhana, the great physician, the giver of happiness, the healer of diseases, should certainly be a bodhisattva with direct perception.

analyzed: sarvena aṣṭa aṅga āyurvaidyam adhigataḥ bhūt
translated: He mastered all eight branches of medical science.

original: tasya khalu punaḥ jalavāhanasya śreṣṭhidārakasya jalāmbujagarbhā nāma bhāryā'bhūt /
analyzed: tasya khalu punar jalavāhanasya śreṣṭhi dārakasya jalāmbujagarbhā nāma bhāryā abhūt
translated: Now, that merchant's son Jalaha, had a wife named Jalajagarbha.

original: tasya khalu punaḥ kuladevate jalāmbujagarbhāyā dvau dārakau putrāvabhūtām /
analyzed: tasya khalu punar kuladevate jalāmbujagarbhāyāḥ dvau dārakau putrau abhūtām
translated: And, Kuladevata, that Jalajagarbha had two sons,

original: eko jalāmbaro nāma dvitīyo jalagarbho nāma //
analyzed: ekaḥ jalāmbaraḥ nāma dvitīyaḥ jalagarbhaḥ nāma
translated: one named Jalambara and the second named Jalagarbha.

original: atha khalu punaḥ kuladevate jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhiputrasyābhyāṃ dārakābhyāṃ sārdhamanupūrveṇa grāmanagaranigamajanapadarāṣṭrarājadhānīṣvanucaṅkramati
analyzed: atha khalu punar kula devate jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhi putrasya ābhyām dārakābhyām sārdham anupūrveṇa grāma nagara nigama janapada rāṣṭra rājadhānīṣu anucaṅkramati
translated: Then, Kuladevata, the merchant's son Jalaha, together with those two boys, gradually wandered through villages, towns, markets, countries, kingdoms, and capital cities.

original: atha khalu punaḥ kuladevate'pareṇa tena kālena tena samayena jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhiputro'nyataramaṭavīkāntāraprāpto'dhvani dadarśātrāntare māṃsabhakṣā vṛkaśṛgālakākapakṣiṇastāṃ diśaṃ dhāvanti yatrāṭavīkāntāre'ṭavīsaṃbhavā puṣkariṇī /
analyzed: atha khalu punar kuladevate pareṇa tena kālena tena samayena jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhi putraḥ nyataram aṭavī kāntāra prāptaḥ dhvani dadarśa atra antare māṃsabhakṣāḥ vṛka śṛgāla kāka pakṣiṇaḥ tām diśam dhāvanti yatra aṭavī kāntāra iṭavī saṃbhavā puṣkariṇī
translated: Then, Kuladevata, at another time, on another occasion, the merchant's son Jalaha, while traveling, reached a certain forest wilderness, and in the middle of it he saw flesh-eating wolves, jackals, and crows running in the direction of a pond in the forest wilderness.

analyzed: tat ṛṭaṣṭvā tasya etat abhūt
translated: Having seen that, this occurred to him:

original: kasyārthamime māṃsabhakṣā vṛkaśṛgālakākapakṣiṇa imāṃ diśaṃ dhāvanti /
analyzed: kasya artham ime māṃsa bhakṣāḥ vṛka śṛgāla kākapakṣiṇaḥ imām diśam dhāvanti
translated: Why are these flesh-eating wolves, jackals, and crows running in that direction?

analyzed: tasya etat abhūt
translated: He thought this:

analyzed: yam nūnam aham tām diśam upasaṃkrameyam
translated: I should go in that direction,

analyzed: yasyām diśi ime maṃsabhakṣāḥ ca vṛka śṛgāla kākapakṣiṇaḥ dhāvanti
translated: in the direction where these flesh-eating wolves, jackals, and crows are running.

original: atha khalu punaḥ kuladevate jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhiputro'nupūrveṇānucaṅkramannanuvicaranyatrāṭavīsaṃbhavā puṣkariṇī tatra saṃprāptaḥ /
analyzed: atha khalu punar kula devate jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhi putraḥ anupūrveṇa anucaṅkraman anuvicaran yatra aṭavī saṃbhavā puṣkariṇī tatra saṃprāptaḥ
translated: Then, Kuladevata, the merchant's son Jalavahana, gradually wandering and roaming, arrived at a pond in the forest.

analyzed: tatra mahāpuṣkariṇyām daśa matsya sahasrāṇi prativasanti sma
translated: In that great pond, ten thousand fish were living.

original: sa tatrāpaśyadbahūni matsyaśatāni jalaviprahīṇāni tatrāsya kāruṇyacittamutpannam /
analyzed: sa tatra apaśyat bahūni matsya śatāni jala viprahīṇāni tatra asya kāruṇya cittam utpannam
translated: There he saw many hundreds of fish deprived of water, and compassion arose in him.

analyzed: tatra adrākṣīt ardhakāyām devatām niṣkramantīm
translated: There he saw a deity emerging from the water up to the waist.

analyzed: sā ca devatā jalavāhanam śreṣṭhi dārakam etat avocat
translated: And that deity said this to the merchant's son Jalavahana:

original: sādhu sādhu kulaputra yastvaṃ jalavāhano nāma matsyānāmudakaṃ prayaccha /
analyzed: sādhu sādhu kula putra yaḥ tvam jalavāhanaḥ nāma matsyānām udakam prayaccha
translated: Excellent, excellent, son of good family! Since you, named Jalavahana, give water to the fish,

analyzed: dvābhyām kāraṇābhyām jala vāhanaḥ iti ucyate
translated: you are called Jalavahana for two reasons.

analyzed: yaḥ ca udakam vāhayati tatas sva nāma anurūpam
translated: And whoever carries water, their family is named accordingly.

analyzed: jalavāhanaḥ prāha
translated: Jala-vahana said:

analyzed: kiyanti imāni devate matsyāni
translated: How many of these fish are there, Goddess?

analyzed: devatā prāha
translated: The Goddess said:

original: paripūrṇāni daśamatsyasahasrāṇi //🔽atha khalu kuladevate jalavāhanasya śreṣṭhidārakasya bhūyasyā mātrayā paramakāruṇyacittamutpannam /
analyzed: paripūrṇāni daśa matsya sahasrāṇi  atha khalu kula devate jalavāhanasya śreṣṭhi dārakasya bhūyasyā mātrayā parama kāruṇya cittam utpannam
translated: There are exactly ten thousand fish.🔽Then, O Kuladevi, Jala-vahana, the merchant's son, felt even more intense compassion.

original: tena khalu punaḥ kuladevate samayenāṭavīsaṃbhavāyāṃ puṣkariṇyā kiṃcinmātramavaśiṣṭamudakamabhūt /
analyzed: tena khalu punar kuladevate samayena aṭavī saṃbhavāyām puṣkariṇyā kiṃcid mātram avaśiṣṭam udakam abhūt
translated: At that time, O Kuladevi, in the Pushkara pond in the forest, only a little water remained.

analyzed: tāni daśa matsya sahasrāṇi mṛtyu mukha praviṣṭāni jala viprahīṇāni dhāvanti
translated: Those ten thousand fish, having entered the mouth of death and deprived of water, ran about.

original: atha khalu kuladevate jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhidārakaścaturdiśaṃ dhāvati sma /
analyzed: atha khalu kula devate jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhi dārakaḥ caturdiśam dhāvati sma
translated: Then, O Kuladevi, Jala-vahana, the merchant's son, ran in all four directions.

original: yasyāṃ diśi jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhidārako'nucaṅkamati tasyāṃ diśi daśamtsyasahasrāṇi jalavāhanaṃ karuṇaṃ prekṣante //
analyzed: yasyām diśi jala vāhanaḥ śreṣṭhi dārakaḥ unucaṅkamati tasyām diśi daśa mtsya sahasrāṇi jala vāhanam karuṇam prekṣante
translated: In whatever direction Jala-vahana, the merchant's son, went, in that direction the ten thousand fish looked at Jala-vahana with compassion.

original: atha khalu kuladevate jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhidārakaścaturdiśaṃ dhāvati sma /
analyzed: atha khalu kula devate jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhi dārakaḥ caturdiśam dhāvati sma
translated: Then, O Kuladevi, Jala-vahana, the merchant's son, ran in all four directions.

analyzed: udakam preṣayamāṇaḥ na ca eva atra udakam upalabhyate
translated: He sent out water, but there was no water to be found there.

analyzed: caturdiśam prekṣate
translated: He looked in the four directions.

original: so'drākṣīnnātidūre mahāntaṃ vṛkṣasamūhaṃ taṃ vṛkṣamabhiruhya drumaśākhāñchittvā yena sā puṣkariṇī tenopajagāma /
analyzed: sā udrākṣīt na atidūre mahāntam vṛkṣa samūham tam vṛkṣam abhiruhya druma śākhān chittvā yena sā puṣkariṇī tena upajagāma
translated: He saw a large group of trees not too far away. He climbed the tree, cut off the branches, and went to the pond.

original: upagamya teṣāṃ daśānāṃ matsyasahasrāṇāṃ drumaśākhābhiḥ suśītalāñchāyāṃ kṛtavān //
analyzed: upagamya teṣām daśānām matsya sahasrāṇām druma śākhābhiḥ su śītalān chāyām kṛtavān
translated: Having arrived, he created cool shade with the tree branches for the ten thousand fish.

original: atha khalu kuladevate jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhidārakastasyāṃ puṣkariṇyāmudakāgamaṃ paryeṣate kuta udakasyāgamanaṃ bhavet /
analyzed: atha khalu kula devate jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhi dārakaḥ tasyām puṣkariṇyām udaka āgamam paryeṣate kutas udakasya āgamanam bhavet
translated: Then, O Kuladevata, the merchant's son Jalavahana searched for the source of the water in that pond, thinking, From where does the water come?

analyzed: caturdiśam dhāvati na ca udakam upalabhyate
translated: He ran in the four directions, but no water was found.

analyzed: sa śīghram śīghram tam udaka strotam samanugacchati
translated: He quickly followed the stream of water.

original: tasyāḥ khalu punaḥ kuladevate aṭavīsaṃbhavāyāḥ puṣkariṇyā jalāgamā nāma mahānadī yatastasyāmudakasyāgamanam /
analyzed: tasyāḥ khalu punar kula devate aṭavīsaṃbhavāyāḥ puṣkariṇyāḥ jalāgamā nāma mahā nadī yatas tasyām udakasya āgamanam
translated: O Kuladevata, the great river named Jalaagama flows from that forest pond, from where the water comes.

original: tena ca samayena sā ndyanyatareṇa pāpasattvena teṣāṃ daśānāṃ matsyasahasrāṇāmarthena sā nadītyadṛṣṭe sthāne mahāprapāte pātitā yatteṣāṃ matsyānāṃ na bhūya udakasyāgamanaṃ bhaviṣyati /
analyzed: tena ca samayena sā ndī anyatareṇa pāpasattvena teṣām daśānām matsya sahasrāṇām arthena sā nadī iti adṛṣṭe sthāne mahā prapāte pātitā yat teṣām matsyānām na bhūyaḥ udakasya āgamanam bhaviṣyati
translated: At that time, for the sake of those ten thousand fish, that river was diverted by some evil being into an unseen place, a great abyss, so that the water would no longer come to the fish.

original: sa taṃ dṛṣṭvā cintayati na śakyata eṣā nadī janasahasreṇāpi tenaiva yathā vāhayituṃ kimaṅga punarmayaikena śakyo bāhayituṃ sa pratinivṛttaḥ
analyzed: sa tam dṛṣṭvā cintayati na śakyate eṣā nadī jana sahasreṇa api tena eva yathā vāhayitum kim aṅga punar mayā ekena śakyaḥ bāhayitum sa pratinivṛttaḥ
translated: Seeing this, he thought, It is not possible for even a thousand people to divert this river back to its original course, let alone me alone. He turned back.

original: atha khalu kuladevate jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhiputraḥ śīghraṃ śīghramupasaṃkrānto yena rājā sureśvaprabhastenopajagāma /
analyzed: atha khalu kula devate jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhi putraḥ śīghram śīghram upasaṃkrāntaḥ yena rājā sureśvaprabhaḥ tena upajagāma
translated: Then, Noble Lady, the merchant's son Jalavahana quickly went to King Sureśvaraprabha.

original: upagamya rājñaḥ sureśvaraprabhasya pādau śirasā natvaikānte niṣaṇṇaḥ /
analyzed: upagamya rājñaḥ sureśvara prabhasya pādau śirasā natvā ekānte niṣaṇṇaḥ
translated: Having approached, he bowed his head at the feet of King Sureśvaraprabha and sat to one side.

analyzed: imām prakṛtim ārocayāti sma
translated: He reported this to the king:

original: mayā khalu devasya viṣaye sarvagrāmanagaranigamajanapadarāṣṭrarājadhānīṣu sattvānāṃ vyādhayaḥ praśamitāḥ /
analyzed: mayā khalu devasya viṣaye sarva grāma nagara nigama janapada rāṣṭra rājadhānīṣu sattvānām vyādhayaḥ praśamitāḥ
translated: Your Majesty, in your realm, in all the villages, towns, markets, countries, kingdoms, and capitals, I have cured the illnesses of beings.

analyzed: tatra amuṣmin sthāne iṭavīsaṃbhavā nāma puṣkariṇī
translated: There, in that place, there is a pond called Aṭavīsaṃbhavā.

analyzed: tatra daśa matsya sahasrāṇi prativasanti jala prahīṇāni āditya paritāpitāni
translated: There ten thousand fish were living, deprived of water and tormented by the sun.

original: taddadātu me devo viṃśatigajā yathā teṣāṃ tiryagyonigatānāṃ jīvitaṃ dadāmīti /
analyzed: tat dadātu me devaḥ viṃśati gajāḥ yathā teṣām tiryagyoni gatānām jīvitam dadāmi iti
translated: Give me twenty elephants, O King, so that I can give life to those who have been born as animals.

original: yathā manuṣyāṇāṃ dattamājñaptaṃ khalu rājñā sureśvaraprabheṇāmātyānāṃ dadata mahāvaidyarājasya viṃśatigajān /
analyzed: yathā manuṣyāṇām dattam ājñaptam khalu rājñā sureśvaraprabheṇa amātyānām dadata mahā vaidya rājasya viṃśati gajān
translated: As the king Suréśvara-prabha had ordered the ministers, Give the great physician-king twenty elephants,

analyzed: amātyāḥ āhuḥ
translated: the ministers said,

original: upasaṃkrama mahāsattva yena hastiśālā upagṛhṇīṣva viṃśatigajān kuru sattvānāṃ sukham //
analyzed: upasaṃkrama mahāsattva yena hasti śālāḥ upagṛhṇīṣva viṃśati gajān kuru sattvānām sukham
translated: Approach, great being, to the elephant stable, and take twenty elephants. Bring happiness to the beings.

original: atha khalu kuladevate jalavāhanaḥ sārdhaṃ jalāmbareṇa ca svaputreṇa viṃśatigajān gṛhītvā nāgaśauṇḍikānāṃ sakāśācchataśo dṛśīnāṃ pratigṛhya pratinivṛttaḥ
analyzed: atha khalu kula devate jalavāhanaḥ sārdham jalāmbareṇa ca sva putreṇa viṃśati gajān gṛhītvā nāga śauṇḍikānām sakāśāt śataśas dṛśīnām pratigṛhya pratinivṛttaḥ
translated: Then, Kuladevata, Jala-vahana, together with his son Jala-ambara, taking twenty elephants from the elephant keepers, accepting hundreds of coins, turned back.

analyzed: yatra jalāgamā nāma mahā nadī pravahati
translated: Where the great river named Jala-agama flows.

original: tatropasaṃkramyodakena tā dṛtīḥ pūrayitvā gajapṛṣṭha udakamāropya śīghraṃ śīghraṃ yenāṭavīsaṃbhavā puṣkariṇī tenopasaṃkrāntaḥ /
analyzed: tatra upasaṃkramya udakena tāḥ dṛtīḥ pūrayitvā gaja pṛṣṭhe udakam āropya śīghram śīghram yena aṭavī saṃbhavā puṣkariṇī tena upasaṃkrāntaḥ
translated: Having approached there, filling those bags with water, placing the water on the backs of the elephants, quickly, quickly, he approached the pond in the forest.

original: upasaṃkramya tadudakaṃ hastipṛṣṭhādavatārya tāṃ puṣkariṇīṃ caturdiśamudakena pūrayitvā caturdiśaṃ ca kramati /
analyzed: upasaṃkramya tat udakam hasti pṛṣṭhāt avatārya tām puṣkariṇīm caturdiśam udakena pūrayitvā caturdiśam ca kramati
translated: Having approached, he took the water down from the elephant's back and filled the pond with water in the four directions, and walked in the four directions.

original: yena yena jalavāhano'nucaṅkramati tena tena daśamatsyasahasrāṇyanudhāvanti //
analyzed: yena yena jala vāhanā unucaṅkramati tena tena daśa matsya sahasrāṇi anudhāvanti
translated: Wherever Jalavahana walked, ten thousand fish ran after him.

analyzed: atha khalu kula devate jala vāhanasya etat abhavat
translated: Then, Kuladevi, this thought occurred to Jalavahana:

analyzed: kimartham etāni daśa matsya sahasrāṇi yena aham tena pradhāvanti
translated: Why do these ten thousand fish run after me wherever I go?

analyzed: tasya punar etat abhavat
translated: He thought again:

original: nūnamete matsyāḥ kṣudhāgninā paripīḍitā mama sakāśādbhojanaṃ parimārgayanti /
analyzed: nūnam ete matsyāḥ kṣudhā agninā paripīḍitāḥ mama sakāśāt bhojanam parimārgayanti
translated: Surely these fish, tormented by the fire of hunger, are seeking food from me.

analyzed: yat nūnam aham bhojanam prayaccheyam
translated: I should give them food.

original: atha khalu kuladevate jalavāhanaḥ svaputraṃ jalāmbarametadavocat /
analyzed: atha khalu kula devate jalavāhanaḥ sva putram jalāmbaram etat avocat
translated: Then, Kuladevi, Jalavahana said this to his son Jalamvama:

original: gaccha kulaputra svakaṃ niveśanaṃ sarvabalataraṃ hastinamabhirūhya ca śīdhraṃ śīghramupasaṃkramya pitāmahasya śreṣṭhina evaṃ vadeha bho tāta jalavāhana evaṃ vadati yatkiṃcidatra gṛhe'bhisaṃskṛtaṃ bhojanaṃ syānmātāpitrorbhrātṛbhaginyordāsīdāsakarmakarasya kṛtaśaḥ sarvamekatra piṇḍīkṛtvā jalāmbarasya hastipṛṣṭamavaropya jalavāhanāya śīghraṃ śīghraṃ visarjaya //
analyzed: gaccha kula putra svakam niveśanam sarva balataram hastinam abhirūhya ca śīdhram śīghram upasaṃkramya pitāmahasya śreṣṭhinaḥ evam vada iha bho tāta jala vāhanaḥ evam vadati yat kiṃcid atra gṛhebhisaṃskṛtam bhojanam syāt mātā pitroḥ bhrātṛ bhaginyoḥ dāsī dāsa karmakarasya kṛtaśas sarvam ekatra piṇḍīkṛtvā jala ambarasya hasti pṛṣṭam avaropya jala vāhanāya śīghram śīghram visarjaya
translated: Go, son of good family, to your own house, mount the elephant that is the strongest of all, and quickly, quickly go and tell your grandfather, the merchant, O father, Jala-ambara says this: Whatever food is prepared here in the house, for mother, father, brother, sister, male and female servants, and workers, all of it should be collected together, placed on Jala-ambara's elephant, and quickly sent to him.

original: atha khalu jalāmbaro dārako hastinamabhiruhya śīghraṃ śīghraṃ dhāvati sma /
analyzed: atha khalu jalāmbaraḥ dārakaḥ hastinam abhiruhya śīghram śīghram dhāvati sma
translated: Then the boy Jala-ambara mounted the elephant and quickly ran.

original: yena svakaṃ niveśanaṃ tenopasaṃkrāmadupasaṃmyaitāṃ prakṛtaṃ pitāmahasyāgra ārocayāmāsa vistareṇa yathā pūrvoktam /
analyzed: yena svakam niveśanam tena upasaṃkrāmat upasaṃmya etām prakṛtam pitāmahasya agre ārocayāmāsa vistareṇa yathā pūrva uktam
translated: He went to his own house and, having arrived, reported this matter to his grandfather, in detail as previously stated.

analyzed: tat sarvam pitāmahena jala ambarāya visarjitam
translated: All of that was sent by the grandfather to Jala-ambara.

original: atha khalu jalambaro dārakastadbhojanaṃ hastipṛṣṭhamupanāmya hastinamabhiruhya yenāṭavīsaṃbhavā puṣkariṇī tenopasaṃkrāmat //
analyzed: atha khalu jalambaraḥ dārakaḥ tat bhojanam hasti pṛṣṭham upanāmya hastinam abhiruhya yena aṭavī saṃbhavā puṣkariṇī tena upasaṃkrāmat
translated: Then the boy Jalambara brought that food to the elephant's back, mounted the elephant, and went to the pond in the forest.

original: atha khalu jalavāhanaḥ svakaṃ putraṃ jalāmbaramāgataṃ dṛṣṭvā hṛṣṭastuṣṭa udagraḥ putrasyāntikādbhojanaṃ pratigṛhya cchittvā tatra puṣkariṇyāṃ prakṣipati sma /
analyzed: atha khalu jalavāhanaḥ svakam putram jala ambaram āgatam dṛṣṭvā hṛṣṭaḥ tuṣṭaḥ udagraḥ putrasya antikāt bhojanam pratigṛhya chittvā tatra puṣkariṇyām prakṣipati sma
translated: Then Jala-vahana, seeing his own son Jala-ambara come, was delighted, pleased, and overjoyed. Taking the food from his son, he cut it up and threw it into the pond.

analyzed: tena āhāreṇa tāni daśa matsya sahasrāṇi saṃtarpitāni
translated: With that food, the ten thousand fish were satisfied.

analyzed: punar tasya etat abhavat
translated: Again, this occurred to him:

original: śrutaṃ me pareṇa kālasamayenāraṇyāyatane bhikṣurmahāyānadhārayamāna ityāha /
analyzed: śrutam me pareṇa kāla samayena araṇya āyatane bhikṣuḥ mahāyāna dhārayamānaḥ iti āha
translated: I have heard that at a later time, in a forest hermitage, a monk who was upholding the Mahayana said:

original: yo ratnaśikhinastathāgatasyārhataḥ samyaksaṃbuddhasya maraṇakālasamaye nāmadheyaṃ śṛṇuyāt /
analyzed: yaḥ ratnaśikhinaḥ tathāgatasya arhataḥ samyaksaṃbuddhasya maraṇa kāla samaye nāmadheyam śṛṇuyāt
translated: Whoever hears the name of the Tathagata Arhat Samyaksambuddha Ratnasikhin at the time of death,

analyzed: sa svarga loke upapatsyati iti
translated: will be reborn in the heavenly world.

original: yannūnamahameṣāṃ matsyānāṃ gambhīraṃ pratītyasamutpādaṃ dharmaṃ deśayeyam /
analyzed: yat nūnam aham eṣām matsyānām gambhīram pratītyasamutpādam dharmam deśayeyam
translated: Why don't I teach these fish the profound dependent origination?

analyzed: ratnaśikhinaḥ tathāgatasya arhataḥ samyaksaṃbuddhasya nāmadheyam śrāvayeyam
translated: I would proclaim the name of the Tathagata Ratnasikhin, the Arhat, the Fully Enlightened One.

original: tena ca samayena tasmiñjambudvīpe dvighādṛṣṭiḥ sattvānāmabhūt /
analyzed: tena ca samayena tasmin jambudvīpe dvighā adṛṣṭiḥ sattvānām abhūt
translated: At that time, in that Jambudvipa, the views of the beings were divided into two.

analyzed: kecid mahāyānam abhiśraddhayanti kecid kleśayanti
translated: Some had faith in the Mahayana, while others were hostile to it.

original: atha khalu punarjalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhiputrastasyāṃ velāyāmubhau pādau jānumātraṃ tatra puṣkariṇyāṃ praveśyaivaṃ cidānamudānayāmāsa /
analyzed: atha khalu punar jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhi putraḥ tasyām velāyām ubhau pādau jānu mātram tatra puṣkariṇyām praveśya evam cidānam udānayāmāsa
translated: Then, at that time, Jalavahana, the merchant's son, entered the lotus pond up to his knees and uttered this aspiration:

original: namastasya bhagavato ratnaśikhinastathāgatasyārhataḥ samyaksaṃbuddhasya purvabodhisattvacaryāṃ caramāṇasya evaṃ praṇidhānamabhūt /
analyzed: namaḥ tasya bhagavataḥ ratnaśikhinaḥ tathāgatasya arhataḥ samyaksaṃbuddhasya purva bodhisattva caryām caramāṇasya evam praṇidhānam abhūt
translated: Homage to the Blessed One, the Tathagata Ratnasikhin, the Arhat, the Fully Enlightened One, when he was practicing the conduct of a Bodhisattva in the past, he made this aspiration:

original: ye keciddaśasu dikṣu maraṇakālasamaye mama nāmadheyaṃ śṛṇuyuste tataścyutvā devānāṃ trāyastriṃśānāṃ sabhāgatāyāmupapadyeyuḥ //
analyzed: ye kecid daśasu dikṣu maraṇa kāla samaye mama nāmadheyam śṛṇuyuḥ te tatas cyutvā devānām trāyastriṃśānām sabhā gatāyām upapadyeyuḥ
translated: 'May those in the ten directions who hear my name at the time of death, after passing away, be reborn in the company of the Thirty-Three Gods.'

original: atha khalu jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhidārakasteṣāṃ tiryagyonigatānāmimaṃ dharmaṃ deśayati sma /
analyzed: atha khalu jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhi dārakaḥ teṣām tiryagyoni gatānām imam dharmam deśayati sma
translated: Then, Jalavahana, the merchant's son, taught this Dharma to those who were born as animals:

analyzed: yat uta asmāt idam bhavati asya utpādāt idam utpadyate  yat uta avidyā pratyayāḥ saṃskārāḥ
translated: That is to say, this arises from that, and from the arising of this, that arises.🔽That is to say, with ignorance as condition, there are volitional formations.

analyzed: saṃskāra pratyayam vijñānam
translated: With volitional formations as condition, there is consciousness.

analyzed: vijñāna pratyayam nāma rūpam
translated: With consciousness as condition, there is name-and-form.

analyzed: nāma rūpa pratyayam ṣaṣ āyatanam
translated: With name-and-form as condition, there are the six sense bases.

analyzed: ṣaṣ āyatana pratyayaḥ sparśaḥ  sparśa pratyayā vedanā
translated: With the six sense bases as condition, there is contact.🔽With contact as condition, there is feeling.

analyzed: vedanā pratyayā tṛṣṇā
translated: With feeling as condition, there is craving.

analyzed: tṛṣṇā pratyayam upādānam  upādāna pratyayaḥ bhavaḥ
translated: With craving as condition, there is clinging.🔽With clinging as condition, there is existence.

analyzed: bhava pratyayā jātiḥ
translated: With existence as condition, there is birth.🔽With birth as condition, there is aging, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair. Thus arises the whole mass of suffering.

original: jātipratyayā jarāmaraṇaśokaparidevaduḥkhadaurmanasyopāyāsā bhavatyevamasya kevalasya mahato duḥkhaskandhasya samudayo bhavati yadutāvidyānirodhātsaṃrakāranirodhaḥ
analyzed: jāti pratyayā jarā maraṇa śoka parideva duḥkha daurmanasya upāyāsā bhavati evam asya kevalasya mahataḥ duḥkha skandhasya samudayaḥ bhavati yat uta avidyā nirodhāt saṃrakāra nirodhaḥ
translated: That is to say, with the cessation of ignorance, there is the cessation of volitional formations.

analyzed: saṃskāra nirodhāt vijñāna nirodhaḥ
translated: With the cessation of volitional formations, there is the cessation of consciousness.

analyzed: vijñāna nirodhāt nāma rūpa nirodhaḥ  nāma rūpa nirodhāt ṣaṣ āyatana nirodhaḥ
translated: With the cessation of consciousness, there is the cessation of name-and-form.🔽With the cessation of name-and-form, there is the cessation of the six sense bases.

analyzed: ṣaṣ āyatana nirodhāt sparśa nirodhaḥ  sparśa nirodhāt vedanā nirodhaḥ  vedanā nirodhāt tṛṣṇā nirodhaḥ
translated: With the cessation of the six sense bases, there is the cessation of contact.🔽With the cessation of contact, there is the cessation of feeling.🔽With the cessation of feeling, there is the cessation of craving.

analyzed: tṛṣṇā nirodhāt upādāna nirodhaḥ
translated: With the cessation of craving, there is the cessation of clinging.

analyzed: upādāna nirodhāt bhava nirodhaḥ  bhava nirodhāt jāti nirodhaḥ
translated: From the cessation of clinging comes the cessation of existence.🔽From the cessation of existence comes the cessation of birth.

analyzed: jāti nirodhāt jarā maraṇa śoka parideva duḥkha daurmanasya upāyāsāḥ nirudhyate
translated: From the cessation of birth comes the cessation of old age, death, grief, lamentation, pain, sorrow, and despair.

analyzed: kevalam asya mahataḥ duḥkha skandhasya nirodhaḥ bhavati
translated: Thus there is a cessation of this whole great mass of suffering.

original: iti hi kuladevate tena kālena tena samayena jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhiputrasteṣāṃ tiryagyonigatānāmimāṃ dhārmikakathāṃ kathayati sma /
analyzed: iti hi kuladevate tena kālena tena samayena jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhi putraḥ teṣām tiryagyoni gatānām imām dhārmika kathām kathayati sma
translated: Thus, O Goddess, at that time, on that occasion, Jala-vahana, the merchant's son, spoke this Dharma discourse to those animals.

original: sārdhaṃ putrābhyāṃ jalāmbareṇa jalagarbheṇa ca punarapi svagṛhamanuprāptaḥ //
analyzed: sārdham putrābhyām jalāmbareṇa jalagarbheṇa ca punar api sva gṛham anuprāptaḥ
translated: Together with his two sons, Jala-ambara and Jala-garbha, he returned to his own house.

original: athāpareṇa kālena samayena jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhiputro mahotsavaṃ paribhujya mahotsavamatto śayane śayitaḥ /
analyzed: atha apareṇa kālena samayena jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhi putraḥ mahā utsavam paribhujya mahā utsava mattaḥ śayane śayitaḥ
translated: Then, at another time, on another occasion, Jala-vahana, the merchant's son, having enjoyed a great festival, intoxicated with the great festival, was lying on his bed.

original: tena ca kālena tena samayena mahānimittaḥ prādurbhūtaḥ /
analyzed: tena ca kālena tena samayena mahā nimittaḥ prādurbhūtaḥ
translated: At that time, on that occasion, a great sign appeared.

original: yattasyā rātryāmatyayena tāni daśamatsyasahasrāṇi kālagatāni deveṣu trāyastriṃśatsu sabhāgatāyāmupapannāni /
analyzed: yat tasyāḥ rātryām atyayena tāni daśa matsya sahasrāṇi kālagatāni deveṣu trāyastriṃśatsu sabhāgatāyām upapannāni
translated: That, at the end of that night, those ten thousand fish died and were reborn among the Thirty-Three Gods in a similar situation.

analyzed: saha upapannānām ca eṣām evaṃrūpaḥ cetasaḥ parivitarkaḥ utpannaḥ
translated: As soon as they were born, this kind of thought arose in their minds:

analyzed: kena vayam kuśala karma hetunā iha deveṣu trāyastriṃśeṣu upapannāḥ
translated: By what cause of wholesome karma were we born here among the Thirty-Three Gods?

analyzed: teṣām etat abhūt
translated: They thought this:

analyzed: vayam asmin jambudvīpe daśa matsya sahasrāṇi abhūvan
translated: We were ten thousand fish in this Jambudvīpa.

original: te vayaṃ tiryagyonigatā jalavāhanena śreṣṭhidārakeṇa prabhūtenodakena saṃtarpitā bhojanavareṇa ca /
analyzed: te vayam tiryagyoni gatāḥ jala vāhanena śreṣṭhi dārakeṇa prabhūtena udakena saṃtarpitāḥ bhojana vareṇa ca
translated: We, being in the animal realm, were satisfied with abundant water and excellent food by the merchant's son Jalavāhana.

analyzed: gambhīraḥ ca asmākam pratītyasamutpāda dharmaḥ deśitaḥ
translated: The profound Dharma of dependent origination was also taught to us.

analyzed: ratnaśikhinaḥ tathāgatasya arhataḥ samyaksaṃbuddhasya nāmadheyam śrāvitāḥ
translated: The name of the Tathāgata, Arhat, Perfectly Awakened One Ratnaśikhin was heard.

original: tena kuśaladharmahetunā tena pratyayeneha vayaṃ deveṣūpapannāḥ /
analyzed: tena kuśala dharma hetunā tena pratyayena iha vayam deveṣu upapannāḥ
translated: By that cause of wholesome Dharma, by that condition, we were born here among the gods.

analyzed: yat nūnam vayam yena jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhi dārakaḥ tena upasaṃkramemaḥ
translated: Now let us go to where the merchant's son Jalavāhana is.

analyzed: upasaṃkramya tasya pūjām kariṣyāmaḥ
translated: Having gone, we will make offerings to him.

original: atha tāni daśadevaputrasahasrāṇi deveṣu trāyastriṃśatsvantarhitāni jalavāhanasya śriṣṭhino gṛhe tasthuḥ /
analyzed: atha tāni daśa devaputra sahasrāṇi deveṣu trāyastriṃśatsu antarhitāni jalavāhanasya śriṣṭhinaḥ gṛhe tasthuḥ
translated: Then those ten thousand deva sons disappeared among the Thirty-Three Gods and stood in the house of the merchant Jalavāhana.

original: tena khalu punaḥ samayena ca jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭyupaśayane śayitaḥ /🔽tasyaitairdevaputrairdaśamuktāhārasahasrāṇi śīrṣānte sthāpitāni /
analyzed: tena khalu punar samayena ca jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭi upaśayane śayitaḥ  tasya etaiḥ devaputraiḥ daśa muktā hāra sahasrāṇi śīrṣa ante sthāpitāni
translated: At that time, the merchant Jalavahana was sleeping on his bed.🔽Those ten thousand sons of gods placed ten thousand pearl necklaces on his head,

analyzed: daśa muktā hāra sahasrāṇi pāda tale sthāpitāni  daśa muktā hāra sahasrāṇi dakṣiṇa pārśve sthāpitāni
translated: ten thousand pearl necklaces on the soles of his feet,🔽ten thousand pearl necklaces on his right side,

analyzed: daśa muktā hāra sahasrāṇi vāma pārśve sthāpitāni
translated: and ten thousand pearl necklaces on his left side.

analyzed: gṛha antare jānu mātram māndārava puṣpa varṣam prāvarṣat
translated: It rained a knee-deep shower of mandara flowers in the house.

analyzed: divyāḥ ca dundubhayaḥ parāhatāḥ
translated: Divine drums were beaten.

analyzed: yena sarve jambudvītāḥ prativibuddhāḥ
translated: By which everyone in Jambudvipa woke up.

analyzed: atha jala vāhanaḥ śreṣṭhī prativibuddham
translated: Then the merchant Jalavahana woke up.

analyzed: atha tāni daśa devaputra sahasrāṇi khaga pathena upakrāntāni
translated: Then those ten thousand sons of gods flew through the sky,

original: te ca devaputrā rājñaḥ sureśvaraprabhasya viṣaye sthānasthānāntare māndāravapuṣpavarṣaṃ pravarṣayanto yenāṭavīsaṃbhavā puṣkariṇī tenopasaṃkrāntāḥ te tatra puṣkariṇyāṃ māndāravapuṣpaṃ pravarṣayantastata evāntarhitāḥ punarapi devālayaṃ gatāḥ /
analyzed: te ca deva putrāḥ rājñaḥ sureśvaraprabhasya viṣaye sthāna sthāna antare māndārava puṣpa varṣam pravarṣayantaḥ yena aṭavī saṃbhavā puṣkariṇī tena upasaṃkrāntāḥ te tatra puṣkariṇyām māndārava puṣpam pravarṣayantaḥ tatas eva antarhitāḥ punar api devālayam gatāḥ
translated: And those gods, raining a shower of coral tree flowers in various places in the realm of King Sureśvaraprabha, approached the pond in the forest. They rained down coral tree flowers in that pond and then disappeared, returning to the divine palace.

original: tatra pañcabhiḥ kāmaguṇai ramanti sma /🔽krīḍanti sma /
analyzed: tatra pañcabhiḥ kāma guṇaiḥ ramanti sma  krīḍanti sma
translated: There they enjoyed the five sense objects.🔽They played.

analyzed: paricālayanti sma
translated: They amused themselves.

analyzed: mahatīm śrī saubhāgya tām anubhavanti sma
translated: They experienced great prosperity and good fortune.

analyzed: jambudvīpe ca rātrī prabhātā abhūt
translated: And in Jambudvīpa, it became morning.

analyzed: atha khalu rājā sureśvara prabhaḥ gaṇaka mahā amātyān pṛcchati
translated: Then King Sureśvaraprabha asked the astrologers and ministers,

analyzed: kimartham adya rātrau etāni nimittāni prādurbhūtāni
translated: Why did these signs appear tonight?

analyzed: tā iva ūcan yat khalu devaḥ jānīyāt
translated: They said, Your Majesty should know that

original: jalavāhanasya śreṣṭhidārakasya catvāriṃśanmuktāhārasahasrāṇi pravarṣitāni divyāni ca māndāravapuṣpāṇi nirgacchanti /
analyzed: jalavāhanasya śreṣṭhi dārakasya catvāriṃśat muktā hāra sahasrāṇi pravarṣitāni divyāni ca māndārava puṣpāṇi nirgacchanti
translated: forty thousand pearl necklaces rained down on the merchant's son Jālinīprabha, and divine coral tree flowers emerged.

analyzed: rājā āha
translated: The king said,🔽What is the reason for this?

original: bhavanto jalavāhanaṃ śreṣṭhinaṃ dārakaṃ priyavacanena śabdāpayan //🔽atha te gaṇakamahāmātyā yena jalavāhanasya gṛhaṃ tenopasaṃkrāntāḥ /
analyzed: bhavantaḥ jalavāhanam śreṣṭhinam dārakam priya vacanena śabdāpayan  atha te gaṇaka mahā amātyāḥ yena jalavāhanasya gṛham tena upasaṃkrāntāḥ
translated: Gentlemen, summon the merchant Jalavahana's son with pleasant words.🔽Then those mathematicians and ministers went to the house of Jalavahana.

analyzed: upasaṃkramya jala vāhanasya śreṣṭhinaḥ etat avocan
translated: Having approached, they said this to the merchant Jalavahana:

analyzed: rājā sureśvara prabhaḥ tvām āmantrayate
translated: King Sureśvara-prabha summons you.

original: atha jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhī mahāmātyaiḥ sārdhaṃ yena rājā sureśvaraprabhastenopajagāma /
analyzed: atha jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhī mahā amātyaiḥ sārdham yena rājā sureśvaraprabhaḥ tena upajagāma
translated: Then the merchant Jalavahana, together with the great ministers, went to where King Sureśvara-prabha was.

analyzed: upasaṃkramya ekānte niṣaṇṇaḥ
translated: Having approached, he sat down to one side.

analyzed: rājā pṛcchati
translated: The king asked:

original: jalavāhana kiṃ nimittaṃ jānīyā yadadya rātrāvīdṛśāni śubhanimittāni prādurbhūtāni /
analyzed: jalavāhana kim nimittam jānīyāḥ yat adya rātrau īdṛśāni śubha nimittāni prādurbhūtāni
translated: Jalavahana, what is the reason that you should know that such auspicious signs appeared tonight?

analyzed: atha jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhī sureśvaraprabhasya etat avocat
translated: Then the merchant Jalavahana said this to Sureśvara-prabha:

analyzed: jānābhi deva niyatam daśa matsya sahasrāṇi kālagatāni
translated: Your Majesty, know that certainly ten thousand fish have died.

analyzed: rājā āha
translated: The king said:

analyzed: katham jānāsi
translated: How do you know?

analyzed: jalavāhanaḥ āha
translated: Jalavahana said:

analyzed: gacchatu deva jala ambaraḥ tām mahā puṣkariṇīm praviśatu
translated: Let Jalam-bhar go and enter that great pond.

original: kiṃ tāni daśamtsyasahasrāṇi jīvanti atha kālagatāni /
analyzed: kim tāni daśa mtsya sahasrāṇi jīvanti atha kālagatāni
translated: Whether those ten thousand fish are alive or have died.

analyzed: rājā āha evam astu
translated: The king said, Let it be so.

analyzed: atha jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhi dārakaḥ jalāmbaram dārakam etat avocat
translated: Then the merchant's son Jala-vahana said this to the boy Jala-ambara:

analyzed: iti atha vyāghryāḥ abhimukham mahāsattvaḥ prapatitaḥ

analyzed: kṛpā matiḥ na kvacid śastram alabhat

analyzed: yathā kāruṇyam te visṛtam iha sattveṣu sumate
translated: As your compassion is bestowed here on beings, O wise one,

analyzed: yathā vai tad deham tyajasi nara vīra pramuditaḥ
translated: As you joyfully abandon that body, O hero among men,

analyzed: śivam śreṣṭham sthānam janana maraṇa arthe virahitam
translated: The auspicious, supreme state, free from birth and death,

analyzed: nirāyāsam śāntam tvam iha na cirāt prāpsyasi śubham

translated: Then that tigress, beholding the Bodhisattva with his body covered in blood, in a mere moment reduced him to a skeleton without flesh or blood.

analyzed: sva tanuḥ iha visṛṣṭaḥ sāṃpratam bhrātṛṇā me

analyzed: mahādevaḥ uvāca
translated: Mahadeva said:

analyzed: kṣudhā anvitām vyaśana śataiḥ samanvitām
translated: Afflicted with hunger and hundreds of calamities,

analyzed: katham mahāsattva vivarjitāḥ vayam

analyzed: tatra kumārasya upasthāyakāḥ diśi vidiśi pradhāvantaḥ kumāra anveṣaṇāḥ parasparam dṛṣṭvā ca papracchuḥ kva kumāraḥ kva kumāraḥ iti

translated: Namely, she saw her breasts being cut off, her teeth being pulled out, and three young pigeons being taken, frightened, and carried off by a hawk.

analyzed: atha devī bhūmi kāmpādu trasta hṛdayā sahasā prativibudhya cintā parā babhūva
translated: Then the queen, her heart trembling, suddenly awoke and became absorbed in thought.

original: kimeṣā bhūtadhātrī jalanidhivasanā kampati bhṛśaṃ🔽sūryaḥ śūlī na raśmirmama ca kica bhūbhajaṃ vayati vā /

original: duḥkhaṃ kurvati me gātraṃ calati ca nayanaṃ svastanaṃ chidyatī ca /
analyzed: duḥkham kurvati me gātram calati ca nayanam sva stanam chidyatī ca

analyzed: svasti me syāt sutānām vana vivaram idam krīḍana artham gatānām
translated: May there be well-being for me and my sons who have gone to this forest grove for play.

analyzed: athā evam cintayantyāḥ ceṭī ca saṃtrasta hṛdayā praviśya devyāḥ nivedayāmāsa
translated: Then, while she was thinking thus, a maid servant, her heart terrified, entered and informed the queen.

analyzed: devi kumāra paricārakāḥ kumāram anveṣante naṣṭaḥ śrūyate
translated: Queen, the attendants of the prince are searching for the prince. It is heard that he is lost.

analyzed: tatra putra hata śravaṇāt ca devī saṃkampita āhṛdayā vāṣpa ākula nayana vadanā rājānam abhigamya uvāca
translated: There, hearing of the death of her son, the queen's heart trembled. With her eyes and face filled with tears, she approached the king and said:

analyzed: deva naṣṭaḥ me priya sutaḥ śrūyate
translated: O king, my beloved son is lost. It is heard.

analyzed: rājā api saṃkampita hṛdayaḥ parama saṃtrāsam āpede
translated: The king also, his heart trembling, became extremely frightened.

analyzed: hā kaṣṭam viyuktaḥ asmi priya sutena
translated: Alas, I am separated from my beloved son.

analyzed: atha rājā devīm āśvāsayāmāsa
translated: Then the king comforted the queen:

analyzed: mā bhīḥ devi putra artham vayam kumāra anveṣaṇa upalabhantaḥ
